title: Multi-focus - runner coach segmented bar chart

content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. The athletic director of a large college has posted an open position for a new running coach. The athletic director plans to compare the abilities of three different running coach candidates (E, F, and G) to predict whether or not a high school runner is likely to improve upon their best running time for the <math alttext="1,600 meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>,600</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> race in college. The athletic director has access to information from tens of thousands of high school <math alttext="1,600 meters" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>,600</mtext><mtext> m</mtext></mrow></math> runners and provided the information to the coach candidates to inform their predictions. The athletic director selected a random sample of <math alttext="400" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> runners who were known to have improved upon their best time in college. Each runner was randomly assigned to one of the three coach candidates. The table shows the number of runners correctly predicted to improve upon their best time in college and incorrectly predicted to not improve upon their best time in college for each coach. RUNNERS WHO IMPROVED IN COLLEGE Coach E Coach F Coach G Total Correctly predicted that the runner would improve upon their best time <math alttext="102" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>102</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="117" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>117</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="101" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>101</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="320" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>320</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Incorrectly predicted that the runner would not improve upon their best time <math alttext="26" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>26</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="22" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>22</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="32" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>32</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="80" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Total <math alttext="128" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>128</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="139" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>139</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="133" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>133</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="400" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) Compare the relative frequencies of runners correctly predicted to improve upon their best time in college for each coach to determine which is highest.

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. The athletic director of a large college has posted an open position for a new running coach. The athletic director plans to compare the abilities of three different running coach candidates (E, F, and G) to predict whether or not a high school runner is likely to improve upon their best running time for the <math alttext="1,600 meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>,600</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> race in college. The athletic director has access to information from tens of thousands of high school <math alttext="1,600 meters" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>,600</mtext><mtext> m</mtext></mrow></math> runners and provided the information to the coach candidates to inform their predictions. The athletic director selected a random sample of <math alttext="400" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> runners who were known to have improved upon their best time in college. Each runner was randomly assigned to one of the three coach candidates. The table shows the number of runners correctly predicted to improve upon their best time in college and incorrectly predicted to not improve upon their best time in college for each coach. RUNNERS WHO IMPROVED IN COLLEGE Coach E Coach F Coach G Total Correctly predicted that the runner would improve upon their best time <math alttext="102" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>102</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="117" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>117</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="101" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>101</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="320" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>320</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Incorrectly predicted that the runner would not improve upon their best time <math alttext="26" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>26</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="22" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>22</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="32" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>32</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="80" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Total <math alttext="128" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>128</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="139" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>139</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="133" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>133</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="400" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) Compare the relative frequencies of runners correctly predicted to improve upon their best time in college for each coach to determine which is highest.

The athletic director selected a second random sample of <math alttext="300" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>300</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> runners who did not improve upon their best running time in college. Each runner was randomly assigned to one of the three coach candidates. The segmented bar graph shows the distribution of the number of runners correctly predicted to not improve upon their best time in college and incorrectly predicted to improve upon their best time in college for each coach. (b) Write a few sentences describing what the graph reveals about the association between coach and prediction accuracy among the <math alttext="300" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>300</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> runners who did not improve upon their best running time in college.

(c) For each coach, give a statistical reason why the athletic director might choose to hire the coach to make predictions for all high school runners applying to the running program at this college. Do not perform an inferential procedure.

The athletic director plans to use the sample data to investigate whether there is convincing statistical evidence, at <math alttext="alpha equals 0.02" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.02</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> that the proportion of runners who would be correctly predicted to have improved upon their best time in college by Coach G is greater than the proportion of runners who would be correctly predicted to have not improved upon their best time in college by Coach G.(d) Name the appropriate test and state, in words, the hypotheses.
(e) State the conditions for the appropriate test, and explain why the conditions are met.

(f) The test statistic for the appropriate test is <math alttext="1.776" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.776</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> (improved minus did not improve). Based on the result of the hypothesis test, what conclusion should the athletic director make? Justify your answer.

topic.text: 1.3: Representing a Categorical Variable with Tables

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Identify an appropriate inference method for significance tests.
